title: Culling badgers 'could spread TB in cattle' because survivors of the killings relocate to new areas
text:
Attempts to stop tuberculosis in cattle by killing badgers may be making the problem worse, a study suggests.

Researchers tracking badgers in or near cull zones found the animals who survived went on to roam over much wider areas.

The area of land they covered increased by 61 per cent – potentially spreading the disease to new sites.

Attempts to stop tuberculosis in cattle by killing badgers may be making the problem worse, a study suggests

Teams from the Zoological Society of London and Imperial College London studied 67 badgers across 20 cattle farms in Cornwall.

They said the findings, published in the Journal of Applied Ecology, showed culling can be counter-productive.

Badgers have been systematically culled since 2013.
